content: Raphaël PestourieSearch this siteEmbedded FilesSkip to main contentSkip to navigationRaphaël Pestourie, PhD, MBA Assistant Professor in Scientific Machine Learning at the School of Computational Science and Engineering, Georgia Tech (2023-present)Postdoctoral Associate, Department of  Mathematics, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2020-2023)PhD in Applied Mathematics, Harvard University––rpestourie3 ατ gatech  δøτ eduWelcome where AI meets scientific computing for engineering applications!My group develops solver-informed artificial-intelligence (AI)-enabled methods that enable efficient partial differential equation–constrained optimization (PDE-CO): a unifying mathematical framework for most engineering design problems, from optics and mechanics to transport and materials.Our goal is to make AI and physics co-evolve, so that learning and computation accelerate one another. In this Engineering + AI paradigm, we integrate the nonlinear fitting power of neural networks with the generalization capability of numerical solvers to design physical systems more efficiently, interpretably, and at unprecedented scale.Research AreasAI-enabled SolversWe build fast, approximate, and physics-enhanced solvers that accelerate simulations by orders of magnitude while maintaining physical fidelity. These solver-informed models use AI not as a black box, but as a partner that learns from theory to fill in missing physics and extend model generality.AI-enabled OptimizersWe develop representation-learning methods that teach algorithms to design smarter. By learning the geometry of the feasible design space, our models enable transfer learning across objectives, physics, and scales.Hybrid Models for Engineering DiscoveryWe bridge theory-driven and data-driven modeling through solver-informed learning, revealing where existing theory breaks down and discovering interpretable corrections.Long-term goalOur long-term vision is to establish a unified framework for AI-enabled PDE-constrained optimization: one that combines fast, physics-enhanced solvers with learned geometric representations of feasible designs. By accelerating both the simulation (through surrogate solvers) and the optimization (through representation learning), we enable scalable, transferable, and interpretable engineering design across physics and scales. These representations and solvers can be shared, lowering computational barriers, democratizing access to high-performance design, and restoring interpretability. Ultimately, this approach redefines how we explore and optimize complex physical systems: making engineering discovery faster, more efficient, and less redundant.Support and recognitionI would like to gratefully acknowledge the support the National Science Foundation (NSF), and the National Institutes of Health (NIH). I am also part of the MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab.I publish in journals such as Nature Machine Intelligence, Nature Communications, npj Computational Materials, Advanced Optical Materials, Small Methods, SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, and IEEE Antennas & Propagation Magazine, and regularly serve as a reviewer for leading journals and conferences in AI and scientific computing.Keywords: AI-enabled PDE-constrained optimization, scientific machine learning, fast approximate solvers, representation learning, model discovery, inverse design, metasurfaces, mechanical metamaterials, end-to-end optimization, hybrid models.LinksGoogle Scholar (link)Twitter @rpestouriePhD (link)Teaching I’m grateful for the highlight about my teaching in the GT CSE press release: “Revered Faculty Uses Teaching to Nurture Students and Research Community”Fall 2023, Fall 2024 (CIOS Honor Roll), Fall 2025: CSE 8803 "Special Topics in Scientific Machine Learning" (I created this new course at Georgia Tech)Fall 2024: CSE 8801 "Linear algebra, Probability, and Statistics" (I created this new refresher course at Georgia Tech)Spring 2025  (CIOS Honor Roll): CX 4230 "Computer Simulations"Information about my groupMy group is hiring!
